In particular, high temperatures and humidity can lead to dehydration, which can cause a drop in blood pressure. On the other hand, cold temperatures can cause vasoconstriction, leading to an increase in blood pressure. Additionally, changes in air quality due to weather conditions (e.g., pollution) can also affect blood pressure.
